text: DREAMS  DREAMS  DREAMS  DREAMS  DREAMS  In the mid-90s, the CDC and Kaiser Permanente discovered an exposure  that dramatically increased the risk for seven out of ten  of the leading causes of death in the United States.
summary: the CDC and Kaiser Permanente discovered an exposure that dramatically increased the risk for seven out of ten of the leading causes of death in the united states .

text: In high doses, it affects brain development,  the immune system, hormonal systems,  and even the way our DNA is read and transcribed.
summary: in high doses, it affects brain development, the immune system, hormonal systems, and even the way our DNA is read and transcribed.

text: Folks who are exposed in very high doses  have tripled the lifetime risk of heart disease and lung cancer  and a 20-year difference in life expectancy.
summary: people exposed in very high doses triple the lifetime risk of heart disease and lung cancer . 20-year difference in life expectancy .

text: And yet doctors today are not trained in routine screening or treatment.
summary: doctors today are not trained in routine screening or treatment . but doctors are not training in routine treatment or screening .

text: Now, the exposure I'm talking about is not a pesticide or a packaging chemical.
summary: the exposure I'm talking about is not a pesticide or a packaging chemical .

text: It's childhood trauma. Okay, what kind of trauma am I talking about here?
summary: it's childhood trauma . what kind of trauma am I talking about here? .

text: I'm not talking about failing a test or losing a basketball game.
summary: i'm not talking about failing a test or losing a basketball game .

text: I am talking about threats that are so severe or pervasive  that they literally get under our skin and change our physiology,  things like abuse or neglect or growing up with a parent  who struggles with mental illness or substance dependence.
summary: threats that are so severe or pervasive that they literally get under our skin and change our physiology, things like abuse or neglect or growing up with a parent .

text: Now, for a long time,  I viewed these things in the way I was trained to view them,  either as a social problem referred to social services  or as a mental health problem referred to mental health services.
summary: for a long time, I viewed these things in the way I was trained to view them . either as a social problem referred to social services or as mental health services .

text: And then something happened to make me rethink my entire approach.
summary: something happened to make me rethink my entire approach . i think it's a good idea to think about it .

text: When I finished my residency,  I wanted to go someplace where I felt really needed,  someplace where I could make a difference.
summary: when I finished my residency, I wanted to go someplace where I felt really needed, someplace in which I could make a difference.

text: So I came to work for California Pacific Medical Center,  one of the best private hospitals in Northern California,  and together, we opened a clinic in Bayview Hunters Point,  one of the poorest, most underserved neighborhoods in San Francisco.
summary: we opened a clinic in Bayview Hunters Point, one of the poorest, most underserved neighborhoods in San Francisco.

text: Now, prior to that point,  there had been only one pediatrician in all of Bayview  to serve more than 10,000 children.
summary: there had been only one pediatrician in all of Bayview to serve more than 10,000 children .

text: So we hung a shingle  and we were able to provide top-quality care,  regardless of ability to pay.
summary: we hung a shingle and were able to provide top-quality care, regardless of ability to pay.

text: It was so cool.
summary: it was so cool . it was a blast . It was cool and so cool.

text: We targeted the typical health disparities,  access to care, immunization rates, asthma hospitalization rates,  and we hit all of our numbers.
summary: we targeted the typical health disparities, access to care, immunization rates, asthma hospitalization rates .

text: We felt very proud of ourselves.
summary: 'we felt very proud of ourselves', says a friend of mine . 'i'm a big fan of the world'.

text: But then I started noticing a disturbing trend.
summary: I started noticing a disturbing trend . but then I started to notice a trend.

text: A lot of kids were being referred to me for ADHD,  or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. But when I actually did a thorough history and physical,  what I found was that for most of my patients,  I couldn't make a diagnosis of ADHD.
summary: a lot of kids were being referred to me for ADHD, or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder . for most of my patients, I couldn't make a diagnosis of ADHD .

text: Most of the kids I was seeing had experienced such severe trauma  that it felt like something else was going on.
summary: most of the kids I was seeing had experienced such severe trauma that it felt like something else was going on .

text: Somehow, I was missing something important.
summary: i was missing something important . somehow, I was missing a few things .

text: Now, before I did my residency, I did a master's degree in public health.
summary: i did a master's degree in public health before I did my residency .

text: And one of the things that they teach you in public health school  is that if you're a doctor  and you see 100 kids that all drink from the same well  and 98 of them develop diarrhea,  you can go ahead and write that prescription  for dose after dose after dose of antibiotics,  or you can walk over and say,  what the hell is in this well?
summary: if you're a doctor and you see 100 kids that all drink from the same well and 98 develop diarrhea, you can go ahead and write that prescription for dose after dose of antibiotics . or you can walk over and say, what the hell is in this well?

text: So I began reading everything that I could get my hands on  about how exposure to adversity  affects the developing brains and bodies of children.
summary: exposure to adversity affects the developing brains and bodies of children . so I began reading everything that I could get my hands on .

text: And then one day, my colleague walked into my office  and he said,  Dr. Burke, have you seen this?
summary: one day, my colleague walked into my office and he said, Dr. Burke, have you seen this?

text: In his hand was a copy of a research study  called the Adverse Childhood Experiences Study.
summary: in his hand was a copy of a research study called the Adverse Childhood Experiences Study .

text: That day changed my clinical practice  and ultimately my career.
summary: that day changed my clinical practice and ultimately my career . that day I changed my practice and my career.

text: The Adverse Childhood Experiences Study  is something that everybody needs to know about.
summary: the Adverse Childhood Experiences Study is something that everybody needs to know about . the study is based on the adverse childhood experiences study .

text: It was done by Dr. Vince Feliti at Kaiser  and Dr. Bob Onda at the CDC.
summary: it was done by Dr. Vince Feliti and Dr. Bob Onda at the CDC .

text: And together, they asked 17 and a half thousand adults  about their history of exposure  to what they called Adverse Childhood Experiences, or ACEs.
summary: 17 and a half thousand adults asked about their history of exposure to what they called Adverse Childhood Experiences .

text: Those include physical, emotional, or sexual abuse,  physical or emotional neglect, parental mental illness,  substance dependence, incarceration,  parental separation or divorce,  or domestic violence.
summary: those include physical, emotional, or sexual abuse, physical or emotional neglect, parental mental illness, substance dependence, incarceration, parental separation or divorce .

text: For every yes, you would get a point on your ACE score.
summary: for every yes, you would get a point on your ACE score . if you were a yes, it would be a good idea to score a ACE point .

text: And then what they did was they correlated these ACE scores  against health outcomes.
summary: ACE scores correlated health outcomes with health outcomes . they did this by comparing the ACE score to health outcomes.

text: What they found was striking.
summary: what they found was striking . they found a stifling image of a man who was able to find a killer .

text: Two things.
summary: two things: a few things: one thing: two things . the other one is a little bit a bit more .

text: Number one,  ACEs are incredibly common.
summary: number one, ACEs are incredibly common . number one is the ACE .

text: Sixty-seven percent of the population  had at least one ACE. And 12.6 percent, one in eight,  had four or more ACEs.
summary: sixty-seven percent of the population had at least one ACE . 12.6 percent, one in eight, had four or more ACEs .

text: The second thing that they found  was that there was a dose-response relationship  between ACEs and health outcomes.
summary: ACEs and health outcomes had a dose-response relationship .

text: The higher your ACE score, the worse your health outcomes. For a person with an ACE score of four or more,  their relative risk of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  was two and a half times that of someone with an ACE score of zero.
summary: a person with an ACE score of four or more was twice the risk of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease . the higher your score, the worse your health outcomes .

text: For hepatitis, it was also two and a half times.
summary: hepatitis was also two and a half times more than heptis .

text: For depression, it was four and a half times. For suicidality, it was 12 times.
summary: for depression, it was four and a half times . for suicidality it was 12 times.

text: A person with an ACE score of seven or more  had triple the lifetime risk of lung cancer  and three and a half times the risk of ischemic heart disease,  the number one killer in the United States of America.
summary: a person with an ACE score of seven or more had triple the lifetime risk of lung cancer and three and a half times the risk of ischemic heart disease .

text: Well, of course, this makes sense.
summary: this makes sense. of course, it makes sense . if you're a fan of this book, it's a good idea .

text: You know, some people looked at this data and they said,  come on, you know, you have a rough childhood,  you're more likely to drink and smoke  and do all these things that are going to ruin your health.
summary: some people looked at this data and they said, come on, you know, you have a rough childhood, you're more likely to drink and smoke and do all these things that are going to ruin your health .

text: This isn't science.
summary: this isn't science . it's not a science - but it is a 'science'

text: This is just bad behavior.
summary: this is just bad behavior . a bad behavior is causing a lot of problems .

text: It turns out this is exactly where the science comes in.
summary: this is exactly where the science comes in . it turns out this is the exact point in the science .

text: We now understand better than we ever have before  how exposure to early adversity  affects the developing brains and bodies of children.
summary: exposure to early adversity affects the developing brains and bodies of children .

text: It affects areas like the nucleus accumbens,  the pleasure and reward center of the brain  that is implicated in substance dependence.
summary: it affects areas like the nucleus accumbens, the pleasure and reward center of the brain that is implicated in substance dependence.

text: It inhibits the prefrontal cortex,  which is necessary for impulse control and executive function,  a critical area for learning.
summary: it inhibits the prefrontal cortex, a critical area for learning . it is necessary for impulse control and executive function .

text: And on MRI scans,  we see measurable differences in the amygdala,  the brain's fear response center.
summary: on MRI scans, we see measurable differences in the amygdala .

text: So there are real neurologic reasons  why folks exposed to high doses of adversity  are more likely to engage in high-risk behavior,  and that's important to know. But it turns out that even if you don't engage  in any high-risk behavior,  you're still more likely to develop heart disease or cancer.
summary: people exposed to high doses of adversity are more likely to engage in high-risk behavior . but it turns out that even if you don't engage, you're still less likely to develop heart disease or cancer .

text: The reason for this has to do with the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal axis,  the brain's and body's stress response system  that governs our fight-or-flight response.
summary: the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal axis governs our fight-or-flight response .

text: How does it work?
summary: how does it work? how do it work . how does the work work? if you have a problem, it will work.

text: Well, imagine you're walking in the forest and you see a bear.
summary: imagine you're walking in the forest and you see a bear . the bear was spotted in a forest in the middle of the forest .

text: Immediately, your hypothalamus sends a signal to your pituitary,  it sends a signal to your adrenal gland  that says, release stress hormones, adrenaline, cortisol.
summary: your hypothalamus sends a signal to your pituitary . it says, release stress hormones, adrenaline, cortisol .

text: And so your heart starts to pound,  your pupils dilate, your airways open up,  and you are ready to either fight that bear  or run from the bear.
summary: your heart begins to pound, your pupils dilate, your airways open up, and you are ready to either fight that bear or run from the bear .

text: And that is wonderful.
summary: and that is wonderful, and that's a wonderful thing. I'm not a big fan of a tad .

text: If you're in a forest, and there's a bear.
summary: if you're in a forest, and there's a bear .

text: But the problem is what happens when the bear comes home every night,  and this system is activated over and over and over again.
summary: the bear comes home every night, and this system is activated over and over again .

text: And it goes from being adaptive or life-saving  to maladaptive or health-damaging.
summary: it goes from being adaptive or life-saving to maladaptive or health-damaging .

text: Children are especially sensitive to this repeated stress activation  because their brains and bodies are just developing.
summary: children are especially sensitive to this repeated stress activation because their brains and bodies are just developing .

text: High doses of adversity not only affect brain structure and function,  they affect the developing immune system,  developing hormonal systems,  and even the way our DNA is read and transcribed.
summary: high doses of adversity affect brain structure and function . they affect the developing immune system, developing hormonal systems and even the way our DNA is read and transcribed .

text: So for me, this information threw my old training out the window  because when we understand the mechanism of a disease,  when we know not only which pathways are disrupted,  but how, then as doctors,  it is our job to use this science for prevention and treatment.
summary: this information threw my old training out the window because when we understand the mechanism of a disease, when we know which pathways are disrupted, it is our job to use this science for prevention and treatment .

text: That's what we do.
summary: that's what we do . we do it all the time . it's a good thing to do it.

text: So in San Francisco, we created the Center for Youth Wellness  to prevent, screen and heal the impacts of ACEs and toxic stress.
summary: in San Francisco, we created the Center for Youth Wellness to prevent, screen and heal the impacts of ACEs and toxic stress.

text: We started simply with routine screening of every one of our kids  at their regular physical,  because I know that if my patient has an ACE score of four,  she's two and a half times as likely to develop hepatitis or COPD.
summary: if my patient has an ACE score of four, she's two and a half times as likely to develop hepatitis or COPD .

text: She's four and a half times as likely to become depressed,  and she's 12 times as likely to attempt to take her own life  as my patient with zero ACEs.
summary: she's four and a half times as likely to become depressed . she'll attempt to take her own life as my patient with zero ACEs .

text: I know that when she's in my exam room.
summary: I know that when she's in my exam room she'll be in her exam room .

text: For our patients who do screen positive,  we have a multidisciplinary treatment team  that works to reduce the dose of adversity  and treat symptoms using best practices,  including home visits,  care coordination, mental health care, nutrition,  holistic interventions,  and, yes, medication when necessary.
summary: multidisciplinary treatment team works to reduce the dose of adversity and treat symptoms using best practices . home visits, care coordination, mental health care, nutrition, holistic interventions and, yes, medication when necessary .

text: But we also educate parents  about the impact of ACEs and toxic stress  the same way you would for covering electrical outlets  or lead poisoning.
summary: we educate parents about the impact of ACEs and toxic stress the same way you would for covering electrical outlets or lead poisoning.

text: And we tailor the care of our asthmatics and our diabetics  in a way that recognizes  that they may need more aggressive treatment  given the changes to their hormonal and immune systems.
summary: asthmatics and diabetics may need more aggressive treatment given the changes to their hormonal and immune systems .

text: So the other thing that happens when you understand this science  is that you want to shout it from the rooftops,  because this isn't just an issue for kids in Bayview.
summary: this science isn't just an issue for kids in Bayview . you want to shout it from the rooftops, because it's a problem for kids .

text: I figured the minute that everybody else heard about this,  it would be routine screening, multidisciplinary treatment teams,  and it would be a race  to the most effective clinical treatment protocols.
summary: the minute everyone else heard about this, it would be routine screening, multidisciplinary treatment teams, and a race to the most effective clinical treatment protocols.

text: Yeah, that did not happen.
summary: yeah, that didn't happen . yeah, it did not happen. i don't know if it happened .

text: And that was a huge learning for me.
summary: that was a huge learning for me, and that was also a learning experience for me.

text: What I had thought of as simply best clinical practice,  I now understand to be a movement.
summary: what I had thought of as simply best clinical practice, I now understand to be a movement.

text: In the words of Dr. Robert Block,  the former president of the American Academy of Pediatrics,  adverse childhood experiences  are the single greatest unaddressed public health threat  facing our nation today.
summary: adverse childhood experiences are the single greatest unaddressed public health threat facing our nation today . in the words of Dr. Robert Block, the former president of the American Academy of Pediatrics .

text: And for a lot of people,  that's a terrifying prospect.
summary: for a lot of people, that's a terrifying prospect . it's scary for many people .

text: The scope and scale of the problem seems so large  that it feels overwhelming to think about how we might approach it.
summary: the scope and scale of the problem seems so large that it feels overwhelming to think about how we might approach it .

text: But for me, that's actually where the hope lies.
summary: for me, that's where the hope lies for me . it's actually where the hopes lie .

text: Because when we have the right framework,  when we recognize this to be a public health crisis,  then we can begin to use the right toolkit  to come up with solutions.
summary: when we have the right framework, when we recognize this to be a public health crisis, then we can begin to use the right toolkit to come up with solutions.

text: From tobacco, to lead poisoning, to HIV AIDS,  the United States actually has quite a strong track record  with addressing public health problems.
summary: the united states has a strong track record with addressing public health problems . from tobacco, lead poisoning, to HIV AIDS .

text: But replicating those successes  with ACEs and toxic stress  is going to take determination and commitment.
summary: replicating those successes with ACEs and toxic stress is going to take determination and commitment .

text: And when I look at what our nation's response has been so far,  I wonder,  why haven't we taken this more seriously?
summary: when i look at what our nation's response has been so far, I wonder, why haven't we taken this more seriously?

text: You know, at first,  I thought that we marginalize the issue  because it doesn't apply to us, right?
summary: I thought that we marginalize the issue because it doesn't apply to us, right?

text: That's an issue for those kids in those neighborhoods,  which is weird because the data doesn't bear that out.
summary: that's an issue for those kids in those neighborhoods . the data doesn't bear that out .

text: The original ACE study was done in a population  that was 70 percent Caucasian,  70 percent college-educated.
summary: original ACE study was done in a population that was 70 percent Caucasian, 70 percent college-educated .

text: But then, the more I talk to folks,  I'm beginning to think that maybe I had it completely backwards.
summary: the more I talk to folks, I'm beginning to think that maybe I had it completely backwards.

text: If I were to ask how many people in this room  grew up with a family member who suffered from mental illness,  I bet a few hands would go up.
summary: if i asked how many people in this room grew up with a family member who suffered from mental illness, I bet a few hands would go up .

text: And then if I were to ask how many folks had a parent  who maybe drank too much  or who really believed that if you spare the rod, you spoiled the child,  I bet a few more hands would go up.
summary: if you ask how many folks had a parent who maybe drank too much, you spoiled the child, I bet a few more hands would go up .

text: Even in this room,  this is an issue that touches many of us.
summary: this is an issue that touches many of us . the u.s. has a lot to say about .

text: And I'm beginning to believe  that we marginalize the issue because it does apply to us.
summary: I'm beginning to believe that we marginalize the issue because it does apply to us.

text: Maybe it's easier to see in other zip codes  because we don't want to look at it.
summary: maybe it's easier to see in other zip codes because we don't want to look at it .

text: We'd rather be sick.
summary: we'd rather be sick if we're sick . 'we'd be sick'

text: Fortunately, scientific advances and, frankly, economic realities  make that option less viable every day.
summary: scientific advances and economic realities make that option less viable every day . fortunately, scientific advances make it less viable .

text: The science is clear.
summary: the science is clear . the science has been uncovered in the u.s. .

text: Early adversity dramatically affects health across the lifetime. Today, we are beginning to understand  how to interrupt the progression from early adversity  to disease and early death.
summary: we are beginning to understand how to interrupt the progression from early adversity to disease and early death .

text: And 30 years from now,  the child who has a high ACE score  and whose behavioral symptoms go unrecognized,  whose asthma management is not connected  and who goes on to develop high blood pressure  and early heart disease or cancer  will be just as anomalous as a six-month mortality from HIV-AIDS.
summary: 30 years from now, the child who has a high ACE score will be just as anomalous as a six-month mortality from HIV-AIDS .

summary: people will look at that situation and say, what the heck happened there? . .
